body.p:
I have been waiting on Mr Touro
or rather in hopes of receiving his orders, to break the protrac
ted silence which has too long ruled between us. And now
anticipating early cause for writing you again I still essay
to explain in part the reasons for my late neglect towards
you. Heavy blows have been levelled at your humble
friend since this pleasure was lastly indulged in; wrongs
have borne down in unmeasured strides & at times my
very spirit has failed me. But the Lord is merciful & altho'
my trials have been moulded into an ordinary casting, yet an
eluding faith, & resignation to what is permitted in the
infinite wisdom of God, have enabled me thus far to rise
superior to the machinations of the evil.

Presuming that you have heard of the
treachery of my late partner who has acted like the most
heartless vilain (for I consider him beyond comparison
with anything that I have ever seen or heard or read of) robbing
me of thousands, most inhumanly too, I hope that you
have made great allowances for the lack of exhibition
of that respect which had previously been my wont in
my intercourse with you. Verily my good friend I have
suffered but thanks to the Supreme, my national Jewish
feeling has held firm midst incessant whirlwinds & storms
which, each, as they arise, seemed to bring inevitable destruc
tion to my every hope in life. You will doubtless excuse
this awkward introduction to a letter which was intended
to be altogether in a different strain, but, “from the fullness
of the heart the mouth speaketh” & even now a great deal remains
to be done, ere I can feel safe from the fowlers snare, the accomplish
ment of which God in his mercy grant unto me—

With regard to congregational affairs I have little new
to state. When I was about to write to you to procure
some of the inside furniture &c I discovered that the
ceiling of the building was so defective as to be really
dangerous & after some weeks lost in convincing
Mr Touro of this he acceded to my wish to have
it taken down. For seven weeks past we have had
incessant rains & therefore could not plaster. The appear
ance of the cholera (which I am happy to say is now in the
decline) made workmen very scarce, & now I think we
can not consecrate the building before March or April
I hope ere many days that Mr Touro will tell me
to order out what we require, but he is dreadfully slow
& the concern has cost him so much already that he
is perhaps to be excused for holding back, particularly
as he gets no very low estimate of the cost of “Sepharim
Bells &c &c from me. Yet all will come right in time
and you must be patient as I have learned to be.

After frequent letters between M N Nathan
& myself I find that he has altered some parts
of the service at St Thomas, nothing of great impor
tance, & that he desires more ecclesiastical power
than is generally allowed a Hazan. I have finally
written him offering him $1600 a year & a house
equal to 8 or 900 more thus making his salary equiva
lent to 24 to 2500 a year. I offer to yield certain privileges
& if possible thus to compromise his demands regarding
the trifling innovations in the service. The only point
that strikes me of any consequence is in his omitting
the repetition of the Anudale?. All his improvements
as to order regular attendence, a choir &c &c I approve

By the bye I have at last succeeded in getting the organ
taken away from the church & think I shall be able to keep

it out altogether, in view of which ?
making the consecration very plain.

The Right Reverent Rabbi Carillion is here
offering his services & starting to ? his way
I think he will find however that he has
come across the wrong man in me. I am
really afraid of this man's being at the head
of anything, he seems to have given trouble where
ver he has gone what do you know or think
of him? write me as I write you this, in
confidence.

All my leisure time is devoted to the interests
of the congregation & still they do not seem satisfied.
So help me God if I err it is from too great a desire
to make everything right. You can not imagine what
an incessant tax it is on me & bothered as I have
been to death with my own troubles & having the labor
of three men to perform in my paper I have been
at times almost crazy & heartily sick of the whole
concern. But please God I'll stick to it & work it into shape
before I retire from office.

Now my good Sir I have fairly stolen the time
required to indite this & it has been at the sacrifice of
attending to other judaic matters. I wish we had a proper
minister here for I am bored to death with liberal minded
“Goyim” who want information & which in fact I am scarcely
able to give them. I have had to day to play the “Roff” to jew & gentile
& what with weddings, circumcisions, funerals &c I am ever
in the go. Besides in an epidemic there are several poor of our
faith who depend on me. I informed the Howard Association of this
fact & stated frankly that I could only aid that society among those
taken with cholera in my immediate neighborhood. Oh if I had
you here how I would bother you with one half of my duties

? fit Judge Womac of Kentucky is here
giving Lecture at the University & wants me to give
him an explanation of all our laws. I take
him to a wedding on Wednesday & then I have to
edify him on the “Jurisprudence of the Jews”
what a business for a pen devil like myself
The worst of it is that every body here knows me
to be a Jew & unfotunately I pass off for one of the
enlightened & well read. Every great man that comes
here by some means or other I am brought into contact
with & invariably conversation turns to the nation.
At all events my dear Leeser I strive to bring no disgrace
& always state that I speak for myself & not for the Nation
that I am very ignorant & rusty formal ? from
a congregation since my 18th year. Almost every scientific
man who comes here brings letters to me from some friend or
acquaintance who kindly volunteers to make me know, but
if they knew him I try to keep quietly in my sanctum
& do my day's & night's work they would probably hesitate.

But this is an abominably egotistical letter & yet it is
just such a ?ear I would naturally write to one whom I
know as I do you, all I can say is write me in the same way
& then we will be even.

Will you give my fondest love to my dear little Aunt when
you see her. Tell her her good husband always calls for me at night
on his way home & I see him constantly through the day. He is well
& will be with me ere long. I have taken advantage of a holiday to write
you although I have been interrupted twenty times since beginning this. My
family are always anxious to hear of your good health & no less so is
your devoted although lately unheard from friend

p.rend: The following is written sideways down the left side of the page.

body.p: ?ink this is very handsomely written for me—can you do as well?
? no visits to day excepting to widows & orphans. No fashionable heartless calls & I had no sweetheart to kiss on the occasion.
